Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Communication Theory Foundations and System Optimization of Femto-Caching and D2D Networks for Wireless Video

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Video streaming is fast becoming the dominant source of data traffic in wireless networks. In order to avoid overburdening the cellular infrastructure, this project investigates new systems that exploit caching to provide high throughput with minimal infrastructure cost. This is pursued by exploiting the asynchronous content reuse of on-demand video, i.e., that most people watch the same videos, though at different times. Two approaches to such caching at the wireless edge ar considered, either deploying helper stations (femto-base stations with a cache, but no backhaul), or caching on user devices together with highly spectrally efficient device-to-device (D2D) communications. The investigations will consider the following main topics: (i) develop policies for optimizing video quality in wireless streaming, (ii) investigate scheduling for single-hop transmission between neighboring devices, (iii) investigate coding for D2D transmission for combining D2D with coded multicast schemes. To complement these theoretical investigations, realistic operating conditions (channels, user distributions, etc.) will be analyzed through simulations.

The result of this work will allow more spectrally efficient transmission of wireless video. This will increase overall video consumption, which is beneficial to the movie/entertainment industry, a key US industrial sector. Furthermore, the suggested systems can also free up many wireless resources that can be more efficiently used for other purposes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless traffic has significantly increased in the past few years and is anticipated to keep increasing in the future. The main drive for this is video traffic, which accounts for about 2/3 of all wireless data. The video demand thus has been one of the main applications of 4G system and is one of the motivations of 5G system. It is thus paramount to find a cost-effective solution to satisfy video demand. To answer this challenge, instead of considering the expensive or non-scalable traditional methods, such as network densification and/or use of additional physical resources, cache-aided wireless networks can satisfy the video demand with low cost via smartly caching popular videos and taking advantage of the unique properties of video traffic, i.e., (i) high concentration of the popularity distribution; (ii) asynchronous content reuse. This promising solution has thus becomes very popular in recent years.

 

As storage capability is introduced in wireless networks, it significantly re-shapes different aspects of the networks as compared to the conventional wireless communications. Consequently, understanding cache-aided wireless networks and providing relevant new designs and analyses from both information-theoretical and practical perspective is very important. There are two major network architecture for cache-aided wireless networks: (i) femtocaching and base station (BS)-caching networks, in which content caching is introduced on BSs and helpers; (ii) device-to-device (D2D) caching, in which content caching is introduced on user devices. This project focused on the latter architecture, and the main goals of this project were to provide theoretical analyses, measurements based on real-world dataset, advanced designs, and practical evaluations to help understanding and improving cache-aided wireless D2D networks.

 

 

Theoretical Analyses and Understanding: Serving as a new architecture of wireless networks, the understanding of the performance limits, general behaviors, and potentials is critical. Also, the theoretical results can serve as the fundamental comparison benchmarks between different network architectures. In this project, theoretical scaling laws of cache-aided networks were investigated considering different network setups. The results indicated that a cache-aided D2D network can significantly outperform the conventional unicasting approach of cellular BSs. Besides, when compared with another recently popular approach based on coded caching, the cache-aided D2D shows no worse (and often better) performance than those approaches, with considerably lower complexity.

 

Experimental Determination and Modeling for Vide Traffic and User Statistics: The benefits of cache-aided D2D networks are largely based on the unique properties of statistics of video traffic and user behaviors. As a result, understanding those properties and providing insightful models based on extensive real-world data is important. In this project, based on an extensive dataset of a widely-used video distribution service, popularity distributions of video requests were determined and modeled. In addition, since different users could have different preferences on videos, individual preferences of users were investigated. Based on the investigations, critical statistics, such as preferences of users on different genres, rankings of genres, and their correlations, were modeled and understood. A generator that can artificially generate individual preferences was thus proposed to help in network designs, simulations, and evaluations.

 

Advanced Designs: To realize the potentials of a new type of networks, smart designs and optimizations from different aspects are necessary. The two most critical designs for a cache-aided D2D networks are: (i) caching policy design, i.e., how a device determines what video file to cache; (ii) video content delivery, i.e., how video contents are delivered using wireless channels. It is obvious that they are correlated. Thus, in this project, both were studied under different optimization goals, e.g., higher throughput and video quality, lower cost, and shorter latency. A caching policy could be static or dynamic. A static policy assumes the policy is fixed for a period, and thus such policy is designed according to network statistics. On the other hand, a dynamic policy can dynamically adjust the caching content according to network dynamics, and thus gain benefits. Both policies have their pros and cons. Our project provided advanced designs for both, and thus helps in enhancing the throughput, reducing the cost, shortening the latency, and satisfying demands of different video qualities.

 

 

Practical Evaluations: All the proposed architectures, schemes, and designs need to be evaluated considering practical setups for proving their efficacy. We thus conducted extensive simulations under the considerations of practical wireless setups, user statistics, and popularity distributions. The results validated the benefits of cache-aided D2D networks promised by the theoretical studies, and showed that the proposed advanced designs can indeed improve the networks.
